caption: This is an excellent memorial. I truly didn't know about the French that were deported to work camps, and this memorial taught me about them. It's a beautiful memorial, very somber, but as you walk deeper into it, there are displays and videos going into detail about the deported. I recommend giving yourself some time to truly explore this and to sit and watch the testimonial videos they have playing. We were there for 2 hours reading everything and watching the videos.

A somber place to visit, but I am so glad we took the time and opportunity to add this into our schedule. As someone from the US, to see a memorial for those sent to the camps was heart-wrenching. I am glad there is a memorial dedicated to their lives. Its free and not very large, but if you take the time to read through the exhibits which are in a few languages, it's worth spending a bit of time here.
Such a lovely and respectful memorial for all those that ultimately lost their lives. Some information boards do not have English translations, so use Google translate camera to read.
Powerfully emotional vital warning to the future here.  What is displayed must not be forgotten; must never be repeated.  Profound.  Brilliantly designed.  Free.
Place you should visit in Paris to understand the French people went through. It was very informative. You can get the information on English, French, German languages

It is a space that realizes the cruel traces of World War II. Not only the photographs and exhibitions of the time, but also the special structure, it is possible to feel the fear of the prisoners. I think that this space of cruelty and horror is not created underground. It is recommended as a place to visit rather than a restaurant in Paris.
Unfortunately, the Memorial closed during our visit. It was renovated due to flood damage. The small park was very nice and quiet! Good to have a rest, from the tourist crowds at the Notre Dame.
Very much worth a visit. Well laid out and informative. Everyone should visit this or places like it to be aware of what can happen

An incredibly interesting experience. What particularly stood out to me was how hostile the architecture felt. Outside, the walls trapped you and inside the atmosphere felt similarly oppressive. It reminded rof your own mortality, in a way. The best memorial of its kind in my opinion.

Unfortunately one of Paris's best-kept secrets, right behind Notre Dame. A small but powerful memorial and museum, in which you can spend a few minutes or hours. Free of charge, no need to reserve, but you might want to call ahead to make sure the place isn't closed to the public during your time slot for school or other groups.
A moment of reflection for so many life lost in this mass murder and will always be remembered.
It is quite a sober experience, but was free! Amazing architecture and design, but brutalistic in design, a good experience

Very moving and worth the visit. In a city of ancient wonders, it is good to remember the not so distant past. The memorial was unique and thought provoking. Right behind Notre Dame, so give it a visit. It brings on all the feels, but is needed to help remember what so many suffered.

This seems to be a hidden gem near the Notre Dame cathedral in Paris.  Our group was the only ones there on a midday.  This really hits home to how impactful WWII was and the impact that the Nazi's had in such an outreaching area.  It really makes you understand how life was like for everyone in the early 1940's.  Some of the information will astound everyone.  For a WWII student this will really shine as a place to have to stop by in Paris.  It is a very emotional place.

We were walking behind Notre Dame when we happened upon this memorial and are so glad we did.  This place was not mentioned in the guide books we read, and after walking through the memorial we were frankly surprised.  A solemn, sobering, sad and very educational experience.  Most of the text was also available in English.  A reminder of a time that we cannot be allowed to forget.

A powerful reminder of the horrors we have committed against one another.  A solemn site to learn and reflect.  Never again.  The memorial is primarily underground in a rough stone style that is intentionally dark and claustrophobic.  The gates to the memorial are not always open, so as other have pointed out, you may end up visiting the garden above without seeing the memorial below.
Small yet quite powerful, somber, impactful memorial. Definitely worth a visit. In addition, centrally located and access is free.

Dedictaed to the French citizens who lost their lives in hte concentration camps, the place is right at the tip of the Ile de la Cite, past the Notre dame cathedral. The entrance is free and so is the audio- guide. The place has some serenity despite the gory details it contains. There is a note on the wall, forgive but don't forget! And that is what makes this place worth visiting. It takes almost 40-50 minutes even if you read each information panel and take the audio-guide tour. And worth spending time to know what people went through and life is a privilege many of us take for granted.

A beatiful place of memorial. The structure of the building and the architecture enhances the realisation of what happend there, and everywhere else in europe. Wonderfully and respectfully build. Since it is verg close to the Notre Dame, I would reccomend anyone to go there.

I’m honestly very very VERY disappointed with this place, it is not because it is a poor memorial, it’s fantastic, but their customer service is ridiculous. On the website they pride themselves on educating the public, they include information and teacher kits, yet when we arrived in a group and realized that they did not take groups. They wouldn’t even allow them to go in four at a time or two at a time. We said we would divide up and go to other locations and wouldn’t linger and they still said absolutely not. I don’t understand why a memorial would refuse people from paying their respects ESPECIALLY when they are abiding by your rules. Terrible customer service. The man said “you are making me tired!” And waved his hand in my face and shewed me away.  As a history teacher, and someone whose family was tragically affected by WWII, with military background whose finally in Paris, I couldn’t be more angry and disappointed.
Beautiful and peaceful square dedicated

Remember to visit this memorial when you go to see the Notra Dame church in Paris centrum. You have to go all the way out to the point of the island, past the church and follow the garden. There is not many people out there, so you have time to read the plates and take in all the impressions. It is truly moving and sad to read the horrifics that happend and the stories from camps and people affected.

Hidden from the crowds of tourists that are around Notre-Dame, this place pays hommage to the deported of WW II. With it's sober and refined architecture, you'll find yourself in a quiet place, that alludes nevertheless to the heavy crimes commited in the past.

A haunting reminder of the horrors of discrimination. Tucked away behind the Notre Dame. Which is actually a blessing as most 'tourists' have no idea it's there in the heart of Paris. Hence no crowds.

Very moving experience. Perhaps it might have reflected the contribution of France to the murder of its Jewish citizens and of Jewish refugees.  But it didn't.The Germans murdered them but the French deported them to be murdered
Very moving memorial. Closed on Mondays. Also located behind the iconic Cathedral Notre Dame in lovely small.park. very reflective location

At the eastern end of Ile de la Cité stands this memorial to remind us the two hundred thousand deported martyrs who died in the concentration camps during WWII. A refuge from the crowds and a place for contemplation. Designed by the architect Georges Henri Pingusson and inaugurated by President Charles de Gaulle in 1962. The Hall of Remembrance *the pebble hall that represents the jewish tradition of placing a stone on the grave of a loved one.
A hidden gem. It's very well made and not enough people know of it.

Unfortunately the welcome host chased me off because I did not want to take a copy of the welcome guide.  The welcome was glacial which is probably why the place was empty despite teeming crowds at Notre Dame just across the street
A hidden surprise... It is an unique structure... A very well designed and displayed memorial. Powerful experience. It's free... Definitely worth a stop!
My friend and I had this place all to ourselves. It is a very reverant and peaceful memorial to those of whom were deported from France (mostly Jewish people) during the second world war.

This monument can be found in the gardens of the Notre Dame. It reminds us all of the cruelty of the Second World War. Let's not forget the horror the people have faced hundreds of kilometers from Paris
Brutal
We stumbled across this gem just steps away from Notre Dame.  Beautifully done all around.
Worth a visit. Design helps draw one into deep reflection on the pain and horrors of the Holocaust.
Very moving memorial and park
I felt like a prisoner in a dungeon: It was cold, damp and made me feel like the many millions who were subjected to the horrors of the holocaust.
Really powerful and heartbreaking memorial.
